title: Free-body diagram - which figure accelerates up

content.question: If the acceleration is directed up the ramp, which figure best represents the free-body diagram for the box and what evidence supports the claim?

choices.label: Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>: There is nothing opposing the force of friction that is directed up the ramp.
Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>: For friction to be directed up the ramp, the box must be sliding down the ramp, and therefore its speed is decreasing.
Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>: Any amount of force pushing the object up the ramp would cause it to accelerate in that direction.
Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>: The pushing force is greater in magnitude than friction and the component of gravity parallel to the ramp.

content.answer: Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>: The pushing force is greater in magnitude than friction and the component of gravity parallel to the ramp.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
